title: 107_hr1623
content: The Act is titled the "Historically Women's Public Colleges or Universities Historic Building Restoration and Preservation Act." It defines historically women's public colleges or universities and historic buildings or structures. The Act provides grants for the preservation and restoration of historic buildings and structures at historically women's public colleges or universities. The Secretary awards grants to historically women's public colleges or universities for preserving and restoring historic buildings using funds from the National Historic Preservation Act. Grantees must agree to conditions such as obtaining approval for alterations and allowing public access for educational purposes. Matching requirements apply to buildings listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The Secretary may provide funds for grants related to historic buildings listed on the National Register of Historic Places, with the grantee required to contribute 50% of the program costs from non-Federal sources. In-kind contributions can also be used for the non-Federal share of costs. The federal government will provide up to $16,000,000 annually from 2002 to 2006 for grants under this section. For fiscal year 2002, $2,000,000 will be allocated for grants to specific universities in different states. The federal government will provide up to $16,000,000 annually from 2002 to 2006 for grants under this section. For fiscal year 2002, $2,000,000 will be allocated for grants to specific universities in different states, including University of Montevallo in Alabama, Texas Woman's University in Texas, University of Science and Arts of Oklahoma in Oklahoma, and Wesleyan College in Georgia. If less than $16,000,000 is available, the amount for each institution will be reduced equally. Funds for fiscal years 2003-2006 will be distributed to eligible grantees on a uniform basis. The Secretary will promulgate regulations necessary to implement the Act, providing grants to eligible grantees on a uniform basis.
